Derek James wrote:

>Of course, NEAT already has a similar feature, in that
>when a new node is added where an existing connection
>used to reside, that connection is deactivated, with
>the potential for later reactivation.  But there are
>not any mutations that, for example, randomly
>deactivate connections or neurons and their
>corresponding connections.
>
>  
>
Ah, that answers my question about dormant genes then. thanks.

>>Thus a balance of 
>>increasing AND decreasing complexity could prove
>>beneficial, even in an 
>>unchanging environment.
>>    
>>
>
>Personally, I think it probably will.  I've had
>discussion privately with Ken along these lines, and
>it's one of the experimental avenues I'd definitely
>like to pursue.
>
>  
>
I entirely agree with you on this one. I've experimented with trimming 
in the past basically because it was necessary to prevent bloat. I 
couldn't say whether it contributed in a positiive way to the 
functionality of the NN's (by removing old inhibitory functionality) but 
combined with a small amount of selection against complexity it keeps 
the population tight and therefore eliminates a lot of unnecessary CPU 
cycles - thus increasing the efficiency of the search as a whole.

Colin.
